div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: . (Aujourd'hui à midi)

Malgré las reprise constatée au Stook Exchange, sur nos valeurs dirigeantes, celles-ci n'ont pas réussi à rentrer en faveur chez nous. Elles sont en général négligées et de ce fait on peut considérer leur légère plus-value comme purement nominale, excepté en Agricole qui a donné lieu à quelques rares transactions. Les titres d'ordre inférieur n'ont pas été mieux partagés. A part une ombre d'attention accordée aux Estates, Delta Land et Comptoir, on a été sur tout le reste silencieux. Bref, les transeotions dans leur ensemble se sont encore raré. fiées. Toute l'activité, et elle a été limitée, s'est concentrée sur les Nongovich Hotels et Cassa di Sconto. Plusieurs arguent de ce manque d'affaires que les vendeurs, dans l'attente de plus hauts prix, se tiennent sur l'expectative. Quoi qu'il en soit, le calme prédomine. Au Caire tout le mouvement porte, parait-il, sur les titres patronnés par la maison De Vries et Boutigny.
L'Agricole progresse de 8 1/4 à 8 5/16, la National Bank de 21 7/8 à 22, la Daïra de 13 1/2 à 13 5/8, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 301 à 303 l'ancienne et de 254 à 254 1/2 la nouvelle.

En hausse également la Béhéra de 21 1/8 à à 21 1/2 et les Nungovich Hotels de 17 à 17 3/4, soit une plus value respective de 3/8 et 3/4 de livre. L'Union Foncière gagne aussi 1/16 à 4 13/16 à la suite d'une demande.

Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, la Cassa di Sconto avance de 44 1/2 à 46 1/2, le Comptoir de 2 3/4 l'ancienne, 2 13/16 la nouvelle et 1 7/8 la fondateur, à 2 13/16, 2 7/8 et 1 15/16 respectivement, les Cotton Ginners de 1 1/4 à 1 11/32 ; seule l'Helonan rétrograde de 7/32 à 8/16.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changement à signaler.

On voit par les quelques lignes qui précè. dent que les fluctuations ne sont pas nombreages, ni importantes et qu'elles indiqnent généralement une avance, conséquence en par. tie de la reprise constatée à Londres et en partie de l'extrême réserve de la spéculation locale. Les affaires ont été presque nulles, comme nous venons de le dire. Que ce soit fante de vendears, comme disent les ung, ou faute d'acheteurs, comme le prétendent les autres, l'avenir le dira. En ce qui concerne les Nungovich, la demande provient du Caire. Comme ce titre a subi naguère des fluctuations fantastiques, on craint, dit-on, de s'y engager. Ce qui semble acquis c'est que les détenteurs ou aoquéreurs sérieux se tiennent encore à l'écart du marché et il faut attendre leur entrée en scène pour se faire une idée de la tournure que prendront les affaires. Jusqu'à présent, ainsi que nous l'avons déjà dit, il s'agit plutôt de spéculation à courte échéance.
faut at nantehonteurs qui ser

div.head: Circulaire A. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Lundi 7 Octobre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 pour cent.

Au Stock-Excbange, le Consolidé a haussé hier de 1/8 à 83 1/4. L'Unifiée a gardé son avance de vendredi à 102 1/4. La National Bank s'est inserite invariée à 22. La Daïra, en nouvelle réaction, est revenue à 13 1/2. L'Agricole s'est raffermie à 8 1/4. La Delta Light & fléchi de 1/8 à 10 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien qui vendredi avait gagné 2 francs a perdu i frano samedi à 699.La Banque d'Athènes a été ramenée à 112. Les Lots Turcs ont accentué leur avance à 172.

Ici, le marchó a été excellent comme début de semaine, et la fermeté de Londres aidant, I il a conservé aisément ses bonnes dispositions sur presque toutes les valeurs. Les plus-values sont disséminées un peu dans tous les compartiments, sauf dans celui des Banques, qui a été très calme. La séance a été, à peu de choses près, consacrée presque entièrement aux valeurs patronnées par notre firme, ainsi qu'à quelqnes autres titres. A de certains moments, l'avimation très nourrie rappelait, sans perdre à la comparaison, les séances du dernier biver, et si l'on songe que la période des affaires n'a en somme pas encore commencé, on se convaincra que les gens avisés étaient ceux qui, au plus fort de la crise, ne désespéraient pas de l'Egypte.
Nous verrons certainement mieux plus avant dans la saison.

Dans le compartiment des Banqnes, la Na tional Bank revient à 22. L'Agricole est moins ferme à 8 1/4-5/16. C'est là un simple effet de l'arrêt de leur hausse à Londres. La Banque d'Orient mollit à 120.

La Delta Light bien que recherchée s'inscrit invariée à 10 1/2. Les Jouissances Faux du Caire haussent à 196-197. La Daïra Sanieh se tasse à 13 9/16-5/8. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est en gain à 694 ainsi que l'obligation ancienne à 302-303. L'Allotment est plus faible à 2 3/8. L'Enterprise and Development recule à 8 7/8 et sa part à 12 1/2. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont occupé à elles seules toute la séance, l'action a haussé à 2 7/8 et les parts après des Agotnations très vives, qní les avaient portées à P.T. 70' ont olóturé P.T. 60. L'Union Foncière a fléchi å 4 578. I/Express Nile Steamers fondateur a haussé jusqu'à P.T. 75 pour finir à PT. 70: D'anglo-American Nile est en bonne tendance à 2 1/2.9/16. La fondateur Brasserie des Pyramides: remonte à 46-46 et les Sucreries à li 38439.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nangovich reprennent leur mouvement et terminent à 17 1/4. Les Beebler. sont ramenées à 6 tandis
invarietausgent dia. Le Creu que l'on faible
que les Upper Egypt se, relèvent à 3 1/16-1/8. La fondateur National Hotels se présente à P.T. 81-82.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'a. méliore à 1 11-16-8/4 et la New-Egyptian à

1 Le "Bankers Magazine" signale le relèvement graduel qui s'est produit depuis un mois dans le cours des valeurs cotées au Stock-Exchange. | "Les 387 valeurs types qui lui fournissent | les éléments de sa comparaison représentaient, au 20 août dernier,globalement, £8,498,130,000; an 20 Septembre, ce chiffre était remplacé par celui de £ 3,581,957,000, soit une angmentation de £ 38,827,000.

"Les Consolidés et les fonds d'Etat étrangers ont montré de la fermeté ; les chemins de fer | américains ont regagné une partie de ce qu'ils avaient perdu. Les mines sad-africaines ont bénéficié de quelque amélioration. Quant agix valeurs de cuivre, on sait combien les dernières semaines leur ont été contraires."
Le Conseil d'administration de la “Société | Anonyme des Chemins de fer de la Basge
Egypte" a décidé de proposer à la prochaine assemblée annuelle, de porter les dividendes à | 30 fos. 75 pour l'action privilégiée, à 6 fos. 75 I pour l'action de dividende et à 5 fos. 75 pour
l'action de jouissance, contre respectivement | francs 29,25 et 4,25 l'an dernier. |_ "C'est une nouvelle preuve après tant | d'autres, du: developpement économique intense de l'Egypte".

Le Conseil d'administration de la "Société des Tramways du Caire" vient de fixer le coupon de l'action de jouissance à 29 francs contre 22 fcs. 50 l'an dernier. L'action privilégiée n'a droit comme on le sait qu'à un dividende fixe de 25 francs. -
Les recettes de la Delta Light Railways pour la semaine au 28 Septembre se sont élevées à L.B. 5,007 contre L.E. 5,083 pour la période correspondante en 1906 soit en dimi. nution de L.E. 76.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Ayril se chiffrent par L.E. 102,994 pour la même période durant l'exercice précédent soit en angmentation de L.E. 16,567.

div.p: Samedi dix-neuf Octobre courant, à neuf heures du matin, au bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des: Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie), à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, des vieux articles se trouvant à Gabbary, ou on peut les examiner chaque jour de nenf | heures du matin à midi, les Dimanches et I jours fériés exceptés.

Les conditions de vente ainsi que la liste relative à ces matériaux peuvent être consultées an Bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généranx à Boulac, Caire, et à celui de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary, Alexandrie, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m., les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.

Pour être admis à concourir le soumissionnaire devra, au préalable, yerser à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire une somme de LE. 10 (Dix Livres Egyptiennes) å titre de dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaréadjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a concurrence de 10% (dix' pour cent) | du montant de l'offre agréée et enlover à ses | frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un
délai de trente jours à compter de la date de | l'Avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur papier timbré de trente milièmes si l'intéressé ne peat pas Assister anx enchères publiques, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu du versement da dépôt provisoire susdit seront adressés | par la poste sous pli recommandé à :
Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des Chemins de fer de l'Etat
| Gabbary (Alexandrie) et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant | la suscription suivante : | "Offre pour achat de vieux articles"
Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne 'sera
pas prise en consideration. | L’Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter | les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite anx soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 3 Octobre 1907. 31043-2-1

div.p: TELEGRAMS.

div.head: FRANCE AND SPAIN
div.p: THE MOORISH COAST.
MADRID, October 7.
Spain, apparently yielding to public opinion has joined the French measures to preven contraband of arms on the Moorish coast, to which she at first refused adhesion. (Reuter) CASABLANCA, October 7.

Much friction exists between General Drude and the Spanish commander regarding the policing of the suburbs of Casablanca. The Algeciras convention entrusted this to Spain but circumstances have arisen requiring Ge neral Drude to occupy these districts in the interests of pacification. The Spanish officer although not possessing the necessary troops refuses to recognise the circumstances of the
recogn P
case.
(Reuter)
RABAT, October 7. M. Regnault and General Liautey have arrived but the bar is impassable owing to heavy weather.
(Reuter

div.head: AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY.
div.p: THE AUSGLEICH.
VIENNA, October 7.

The chief change in the new Austro-Hungarian Ausgleich is the substitution of a commercial treaty for the customs union. It is understood that Hungary's contributions to the common expenses will be increased by 1%. (Reuter)
VIENNA, October 7.

The details of the Ausgleich have not been stated but the greatest satisfaction is felt both in Austria and Hungary regarding the friendly termination for a decade of the struggle which lasted since 1897. The consensus of opinion is that the Emperor largely contributed towards the agreement. (Reuter)
BUDAPEST, October 7.
M. Kossuth declared that the compromises satisfied the two nations.
(Havas)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
div.p: OBLIGATORY ARBITRATION.
THE HAGUE, October 7.

The Arbitration Committee of the Convention on Saturday exhaustively debated and adopted by 30 votes to 6 the principle of obligatory arbitration on certain specific subjects set forth in the general convention. The minority consisted of Germany, Austria, Rumania, Greece, Turkey, and China. Four countries abstained from voting, including Japan. (Reuter)
THE CUAMATAS DEFEATED.
CHIEF KRAAL CAPTURED.
LISBONE, October 7.
The Portuguese troops have decisively defeated the Cuamatas and have captured the chief kraal. They have lost 2 killed and 14 wounded. (Reuter)
U. S. A. AND JAPAN.
COOLIE EMIGRATION.
LONDON, October 7.

The "Morning Post" learns from Washington on good authority that the principal reason of Mr. Taft's visit to Japan is to inform the latter that unless the emigration of coolies to America is checked the Exclusion Bill will be introduced to Congress during the coming session.
(Renter)
MACEDONIA.
MURDER OF GREEKS.
SALONIKA, October 7.

A Bulgarian band of 200 attacked the Greek village of Negovani in the vilayet of Monastir. Details of the occurrence are lacking. Another Bulgarian band killed four Greeks working in vineyards near Serres.
(Reuter)
THE ABYSSINIAN MISSION.
RECEPTION BY THE POPE.
ROME, October 7. The Pope has received the Abyssinian mis sion which has aroused great interest at the Vatican.
(Reuter
COTTON HANDLERS UNION
8,000 MEMBERS STRIKE.
NEW ORLEANS, October 7.
8,000 members of the Cotton Handlers Union here have struck, thus stopping all shipments of cotton.
(Reuter
OE
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
LETTER TO THE "TEMPS."
PARIS, October 7.
In a letter addressed to the "Temps" Mr. Lambert, ex-director of the Khedivial Law School, explains his disagreement with Mr. Dunlop.
(Havas
GERMAN DIPLOMATIC
SERVICE.
BERLIN, October 7.

The Foreign Secretary, Herr Tschirschky, has been appointed Ambassador at Vienna in place of Count de Wedel who becomes Gover nor of Alsace-Lorraine in succession to Prince Hohenlohe who has resigned on the ground of age. Herr W. de Schoen at. St. Petersburg replaces Herr Tschirschky. (Reuter)
BERLIN, October 7.
M. Schoen replaces M. De Tchirsky who has been appointed Ambassador at Vienna.
(Havas)
GREAT BRITAIN'S TRADE.
LONDON, October 7
The imports for the month of September shews an increase of £281,441 and the exports £4,631,167 over the same period last year.
(Reuter)
PARIS COUNCILLORS IN LONDON.
LONDON, October 7.
The Paris Councillors have been entertained at a banquet at the Guildhall.
(Reuter)
THE ARGELIER CASE.
MONTPELLIER, October 7.
The Argelier case will come before the court of assizes.
(Havas)
PLAGUE AT ORAN.
ORAN, October 7.
There have been two fresh cases of plague here. The granting of pratique has been post
poned.
(Reuter)
ORAN, October 7. Two new cases of plague have been notified.
(Havas)
GAS STRIKE` IN ITALY.
ROME, October 7.
The workmen of the gas-works at Milan, Genoa, and Sanpierdarena are on strike.
(Havas)
GRAND DUKE OF BADEN'S FUNERAL.
CARLSRUHE, October 7. The Kaiser and the Imperial Princes were present at the funeral of the Grand Duke.
(Havas)

EGYPT'S TRADE.
GUNNY BAGS

The statistics, of the imports of sacks into Egypt during the past five years, clearly show the monopoly which India practically is has of the trade, and also the heavy increase the in price which has recently taken place in er) the article.

With regard to the heavy drop in the re turns for 1906 compared with those of the N. previous year we may mention that in 1905 a big cotton crop was expected and heavy shipments of bags made accordingly. The hopes of the merchants were not realized, and large stocks were consequently carried forward.
The whole of the jute supply for Calcutta, ers Dundee, and elsewhere comes from the Bengal all district, which is the only country where jute r) has so far been successfully grown. The better

qualities of fibre for making flour and cement bags (and also for use in various other trades) go to Dundee, whilst, so far as Egypt is concerned, the cheaper varieties are worked up in Calcutta into sacks for transporting cotton, cotton seed, grain and onions. Thus from the Egyptian merchant's point of view Dundee and Calcutta can hardly be said to be competitors, Ir. since, broadly speaking, the articles made in aw each place are quite different.
Cotton and Grain Bags.

The ordinary 3 lbs sack used especially for wheat, barley, and other kinds of grain, the 5 lbs cotton seed bag and the 3 and 4 lbs cotton sacks, all made in India, are the ones principally found on this market. The two former are 60 in: by 30 in, and have 6

porter and 8 shot. The 3 lbs and 3 lbs y cotton sacks are 85 by 45, are 85 by 45, contain 9 in porter and 10 shot, and are generally made er from a certain quality of jute known as ce Hessian cloth. The tendency, at any rate of amongst Europeans, is to use the heavier g sack, as it is found that the additional cost
e

is compensated by the better wearing quali ties. On the other hand, a factor in favour of the lighter bag is the keenness of the native to change the heavier sack for an inferior one, it he has the slightest opportunity of doing so.
Flour Bags.
These bags which, of course, must have a much closer texture than the ones for cotton

or cotton seed-in point of fact, a certain er amount of retaining material is worked into ts the fibre in order to prevent the flour passing through the meshes-are almost entirely imported from Dundee, as the Calcutta mills lack the skilled labour for making a high grade flour bag, and, further, their machinery is not adapted for this kind of work. The shipments, however, are only small as the bags in which the flour arrives are subsequently washed and then used again after milling.
d Sugar Bags.

The "Daira" sugar bags containing 6 porter and 8 shot, measuring 29 by 42 1/2, and weighing 2 1/2 lbs are those commonly used in the work of carrying the sugar from the factory to the refinery. It is estimated that t about 600,000 of these bags reach Egypt ) annually.
Onion Bags.

Various qualities weighing 10, 11, and 12 } ounces are employed in the onion trade here. The bags are of Indian manufacture, and are usually 9 porter and 10 shot, the size being 40 by 24. The imports are about 2,000,000 a year.
Special Sized Bags
The orders for bags of special sizes or weights usually find their way to Dundee since, for 1. obvious reasons the Indian mills usually con
fire themselves to stock sizes.

As a matter of possible interest to Dundee mill owners, we may say that the freight from Calcutta and Suez runs about 25/- and 30/- a ton of 50 cubic feet, whilst the railway charges from the latter port to Alexandria or the Delta villages are 5 paras for each 5 lbs grain bag, 3 paras for each 3 lbs bag, and 3 paras for each 3 lbs bag. (40 paras equal two pence half penny).
There is not a large trade between Egypt and the Sudan, though a certain quantity go up to Khartoum in connection with the gum industry.

Under the heading "Bags for the Egyptian Army-Supplies from India" the following somewhat ominous announcement recently appeared in the "Indian Trade Journal," which is an official organ of the Indian Government.

"In our issue of 19th July 1906, we recorded the steps taken by this Department to obtain for Indian manufacturers of te goods a share in certain Egyptian Government contracts that had been notified in he Board of Trade Journal. Samples of he flour sacks then in question and also of gin sacks subsequently wanted were procured from the Department of Supplies of he Egyptian Army and were placed on exhibit on at the office of this Department, and attention was drawn to these from time to time." (To be concluded).
(British Chamber of Commerce Bulletin

div.head: MACEDONIAN FINANCIAL COMMISSION.
div.p: MR. R.W. GRAVES'S IMPORTANT APPOINTMENT

The appointment of Mr. R.W. Graves, his Majesty's Consul General at Salonica, to be the British Delegate on the Financial Commission for Macedonia has given general satisfaction, says the "Times" correspondent at Constantinople. It is felt that his knowledge of the country and the language will strengthen the commission at a point at which it has hitherto been deplorably weak, for, strange as it may appear, none of the other members is able to read a Turkish document or to speak to a Turkish official in his own tongue. As it is now proposed to charge the commission with the task of controlling the judicial administration, it is high time that at any rate one of the members should be capable of reading the "procès verbal" of a trial without having to get it translated and of conversing with a Turkish Judge or witness without the assistance of an interpreter. Mr. Graves, moreover, has served for many years in Balgaria, and knows the language and people of that country as intimately as he knows Turkish and the Turks and his long experience of Balkan affairs will be of use in other ways. The fact that the Powers hitherto have attached so little importance to qualifications of this kind in selecting agents to carry out reforms is one of the main reasons why public opinion in Constantinople has been so sceptical as to their sincerity. Apart from such considerations, everybody who knows Mr. Graves is delighted with this proof that the excellent work which he has done during more than 20 years in the Levant Consular service is appreciated by the Government, especially as that service has not been very generously treated in the past.
THE PARTITION OF TURKEY.

An old diplomatist, writing in the "Rhenish Westphalian Gazette," considers that there must be some deeper reason for the great change in Russian policy manifested in the new Convention with England than appears on the surface and suggests that it is to be found in the partition of Turkey.

England, he says, has not reckoned in vain with the weakly and pacific nature of the Emperor of Russia and with the petticoat politics that dominate at St. Petersburg, "to which influences alone is due the victory over GermanRussian policy in foreign affairs." With the aid of the present policy in St. Petersburg he contends that England has succeeded in concluding what, for Russia, is an unnatural agreement, and that it will continue to direct Russian policy in wrong paths. A bait must, however, he asserts, have been offered, even to impotent Russia to induce her to desist from crossing British plans in the Indian Ocean, and rumour says that the bait is Turkey.

The question of the partition of Turkey must come up on the death of the present Sultan, and when this event occurs Russia is to be given a free hand in the Balkans and Asia Minor, while Persia and the Euphrates countries are to fall to England. That England and Russia have come to a secret understanding on the subject of Turkey is, in the opinion of the old diplomatist, more clear from the fact that all mention of this subject is avoided in the Convention. He concludes with a prophecy that this understanding between England and Russia will not long endure.
PRICE OF WHISKY.

The Distillers Company (Limited), which is the largest whisky-producing concern in the world intimate that their whiskies are increased in price 2d per gallon to Scottish and English distillers, and 3d per gallon to Irish distillers, all 25 O.P. gallon. The Distillers Company practically control the production of the grain whisky of the United Kingdom, and their products are almost entirely used for blending purposes. That is to say, grain whisky passes to large blenders for blending with the Highland and Lowland malt whiskies. The movement, therefore, by the large producers of grain whisky must have far-reaching effects.

Already the Highland and the Island distillers have had conferences, with the object of increasing the price of whisky, and this action by the Distillers Company is sure to be followed by an all-round advance. The retail price will be unaffected. The reason of the rise is the increased cost of fuel and barley.
LORD MINTO AND INDIAN MOSLEMS

The Bombay delegates to the deputation of prominent Mahomedans which waited upon Lord Minto last October have approached Nawab Mohsin-ul-Mulk, the hon. secretary of the deputation, requesting him, in the absence from the country of the president, the Aga Khan, to take steps for conveying to the Viceroy the gratitude of the deputation, on behalf of the Indian Moslems, for the constitutional reforms adumbrated in the recently-published letter to the local administrations. They regard the document as a sincere and timely attempt on, the part of Government to respond to the practical ideals of liberty and progress which are stirring the natural leaders of all classes and sects in this country, provision being made for due and adequate protection of the great Mahomedan minority India. Upon the ultimate satisfactory settlement of the details of the proposed reforms depends not a little the fate of his Majesty's Indian Mahomedan subjects, and these details should be carefully studied by the leaders of the community in each of the provinces. Meanwhile, they should express their gratitude to Lord Minto for the due fulfilment of the promises he made to the deputation. At a critical period in the history of British India, his Excellency had, on his own initiative, set forth a scheme of reforms which would in the main command the approval of all moderate and sober leaders of public opinion in India; and there could be no doubt that his name would be enrolled with those distinguished sons of Great Britain who had from time to time helped to consolidate the foundations of British rule in India,
THE PLACE OF THE SMALLER NATIONS.

The Pan-Celtic Congress, which has this week been holding in Edinburgh much learned and curious revelry, is a noteworthy exemplification of that development of racial self-consciousness which has been so widespread a feature of the last half-century. As the progress of material civilisation tends to knit peoples more and more closely together by the improvement of the means of communication and transit, there seems to be a natural reaction of individualism, which causes every smaller racial unit to rally all its resources and assert itself with a newfound enthusiasm and fervour. There is hardly a country in Europe which does not show traces of this racial ferment, working in one guise or another.-"Times,"
WHERE DO THE BIRDS DIE?

The return of the gulls, referred to in this column yesterday, suggests an interesting question. We see them come and go in great flocks in the spring and autumn, and we have them with us all the winter. But how many people, even of those familiar with the great breeding grounds, have ever seem a dead gull whose death could be attributed merely to age 1 Similarly, of the myriads of sparrows in London

-how many are ever seem dead except from violence. And so for the other representatives of far and feather-with, of course, a reservation in respect of game birds and animals, there is a puzzle which few can solve. Where and how do the wild things die ?
